commit.title: [ide] Provide tags file for separate build.
commit.message:
[ide] Provide tags file for separate build.

Packages have long wanted to be able to build CoqIDE against an
installed Coq instead of having to rebuild certain parts of Coq
itself.

This is in fact since quite a bit of time, as shown by other toplevels
in OPAM such as `coq-serapi`.

We thus profit from some recent changes and provide a `_tags` file
that packages can use to build CoqIDE using `ocamlbuild`.

Dune provides much better support for this scenario, as it even
understands the `coqide.opam` file; however this file is small enough
as to submit too.

This could be backported to 8.8.1 but the conditions on the protocol
files for the `_tags` file have to be manually added, of better, such
files moved to its own directory as done in `master`.

Note that as of today, the resulting files have to be installed in the
same place where the `coqworker*` binaries are installed.

This could be improved by tweaking the search heuristic.

Note that as of today, the resulting files have to be installed in the
same place where the `coqworker*` binaries are installed.

This could be improved by tweaking the search heuristic.

commit.title: [ide] Provide tags file for separate build.
commit.message:
[ide] Provide tags file for separate build.

Packages have long wanted to be able to build CoqIDE against an
installed Coq instead of having to rebuild certain parts of Coq
itself.

This is in fact since quite a bit of time, as shown by other toplevels
in OPAM such as `coq-serapi`.

We thus profit from some recent changes and provide a `_tags` file
that packages can use to build CoqIDE using `ocamlbuild`.

Dune provides much better support for this scenario, as it even
understands the `coqide.opam` file; however this file is small enough
as to submit too.

This could be backported to 8.8.1 but the conditions on the protocol
files for the `_tags` file have to be manually added, of better, such
files moved to its own directory as done in `master`.

Note that as of today, the resulting files have to be installed in the
same place where the `coqworker*` binaries are installed.

This could be improved by tweaking the search heuristic.
